awd_titl_txt: High Precision Mechanical Tiltmeter for Advanced LIGO
awd_abstract_narration:
Unprecedented levels of seismic isolation are required to achieve the sensitivity necessary to observe gravitational waves in Advanced LIGO. This award supports the development of instruments and techniques to ammeliorate the effect of seismic vibrations on the overall detector performance. The active seismic isolation stages in Advanced LIGO employ seismometers located on the ground and on the isolated platform to measure and subtract ground motion. However, horizontal seismometers cannot distinguish between ground tilt and horizontal acceleration. Tilt-horizontal coupling complicates the feedback and is a significant noise source for seismic isolation in Advanced LIGO. This award supports the development of a high precision inertial sensor to measure horizontal tilt independently from horizontal acceleration. Removing tilt and tilt noise from the horizontal seismometer channels will improve Advanced LIGO seismic isolation.

The tiltmeters we are developing are unique and not commercially available. These instruments may have applications in other fields of science such as in geophysics, well beyond gravitational wave research. This award not only supports the development of a device for Advanced LIGO but it also serves to maintain and strengthen synergistic activities of our table-top gravity group with the gravitational wave detection community. The technical developments and experiments are carried out by a university-based research group, which has a strong tradition of educating undergraduate students, graduate students and postdocs in building precision mechanical instruments. With the expertise gained through projects, such as developing a one-of-a-kind tiltmeter, our students fill positions in academia as well as highly skilled positions in industry. Our group is strongly committed to outreach on all levels.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The aim of this project was to develop high-precision tilt-sensors to improve the isolation from ground motion in the Laser Interferometer Gravitational-wave Observatory. The tilt-sensors are necessary because LIGO uses seismometers for seismic isolation; seismometers cannot distinguish between horizontal acceleration and slow tilts caused by wind, for example. Such tilt-sensors needed to be better than commercially available sensors by several orders of magnitude.

We developed prototype sensors which had the sensitivity to measure ground-tilts induced by wind-pressure on the walls of the LIGO buildings and thus could be used to improve isolation from ground motion.The first tilt-sensor, referred to as the Beam-Rotation-Sensor (BRS-X) was installed as a proof-of-prinicple experiment at the X-End-Station at LIGO Hanford Observatory (LHO) in Fall 2014. The experiment was successful and showed that tilt-noise could be very effectively subtracted from a co-located seismometer. A second tilt-sensor (BRS-Y) was then commissioned and installed for the Y-End-Station at LHO. Robust control systems and interfaces to the LIGO data acquisition systems were developed for these sensors and improved seismic isolation was demonstrated. The BRSs are currently being used to improve the duty cycle of the observatory under high wind conditions.

In addition we have developed a high-precision compact tilt-sensor which can measure tilts from ambient ground-waves at higher frequencies. This sensor uses a new innovative fiber-otpic interferometer readout with a factor of 10 lower readout noise. It is also deployed at LHO to measure the direct gravitational forces on the LIGO mirrors from ambient ground motion. This instrument is suitable to be mounted directly on the suspended optical platforms, from which the test-masses are suspended, and thereby significantly improve the active seismic isolation system.

Modified by: Jens H Gundlach
